title.narrative: Do No Harm Policy in Biodiversity

description.narrative:
The Goal of the Capfish/FOSTER project is to improve the socio-economic conditions of the fishing communities and environmental sustainability of the (Western) Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve (TSBR) through community-centered interventions reaching over 200000 women, men and children in Cambodia. The Capfish/FOSTER Project led by Oxfam and 14 partners has 3 Objectives: 1)Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have increased access to safe water supply, hygiene and sanitation services2) Vulnerable and poor girls and boys are provided with increased availability and accessibility to education and can successfully transition through school 3) Fishing communities in the Tonle Sap have developed sustainable alternative livelihoods. In order to respond to the urgent need for fishing communities to diversify their livelihoods and reduce environmental pressures to the TSBR.
As a means of safeguarding the integrity of thebiodiversity in the TSBR, using tried and tested methodologies that compensate communities with implementing good practices, Wild life Conservation Society(WCS )will train the entire consortium ( all partners ) on integrating principles of ‘Do No Harm to Biodiversity’ and wildlife conservation incentive payments and payments for ecosystem services.

participating-org.narrative:
The WCS Cambodia Country Program was established on December 13, 1999. We work under the framework of a long-term Memoranda of Agreement with the Royal Government of Cambodia through the ministries most directly involved in nature conservation, the Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry 6 and Fisheries. We have long-established collaboration with local NGOs, community groups, companies and a range of government agencies. The WCS Cambodia Program is characterized by a long-term field presence in key landscapes, our ability to engage constructively with governments, our focus on science-based solutions and our strong track record of seeking solutions with the private sector. The WCS Cambodia Program mainly works in four main areas, the Tonle Sap Lake and Floodplain, the Northern Plains of Preah Vihear Province, Srey Ambel and the Koh Kong Reptile Conservation Centre in Koh Kong Province and The Eastern Plains in Mondulkiri Province. In addition to landscape-based work, WCS serveson high-level government-donor Technical Working Groups on Forestry and Fisheries and is involved in policy development. We are trusted partners in the development of new modalities for community-based natural resource management, including Indigenous Communal Land Titling, award winning community based eco-tourism, incentive based agri-environment payments, the Communitybased Production Forestry and the integrated farming and biodiversity conservation areas (for conservation of non-forest ecosystems).
- Goal: N/A - Vision: WCS envisions a world where wildlife thrives in healthy lands and seas, valued by societies that embrace and benefit from the diversity and integrity of life on earth. - Mission: WCS saves wildlife and wild places worldwide through science, conservation action, education, and inspiring people to value nature - Value: Respect, Accountability <(>&<)> Transparency, Innovation, Diversity <(>&<)> Inclusion, Collaboration, Integrity.
